title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.001
frontText: What are three key objectives of cybersecurity programs?
backText: Confidentiality, integrity, and availability

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.002
frontText: What are specific goals of confidentiality, integrity, and availability?
backText: Confidentiality ensures that unauthorized individuals are not able to gain access to sensitive information; integrity ensures that there are no unauthorized modifications to information or systems, either intentionally or unintentionally; and availability ensures that information and systems are ready to meet the needs of legitimate users at the time those users request them.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.003
frontText: What are three key threats to cybersecurity programs?
backText: Disclosure, alteration, and denial

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.004
frontText: What term describes the unauthorized modification of information?
backText: Alteration is the unauthorized modification of information and is a violation of the principle of integrity. Denial is the unintended disruption of an authorized user’s legitimate access to information.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.005
frontText: Name all five risk categories.
backText: Financial, reputational, strategic, operational, and compliance

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.006
frontText: What are four security control categories?
backText: Technical controls, operational controls, managerial controls, and physical controls

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.007
frontText: What are some examples of technical controls?
backText: Firewall rules, access control lists, intrusion prevention systems, and encryption

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.008
frontText: What are some examples of operational controls?
backText: User access reviews, log monitoring, and vulnerability management

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.009
frontText: What are some examples of managerial controls?
backText: Periodic risk assessments, security planning exercises, and the incorporation of security into the organization’s change management, service acquisition, and project management practices

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.010
frontText: Name all security control types
backText: Preventive controls, detective controls, corrective controls, deterrent controls, compensating controls, and directive controls

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.011
frontText: What are three states where data might exist?
backText: Data at rest, data in transit, data in use

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.012
frontText: What is data encryption?
backText: Encryption technology uses mathematical algorithms to protect information from prying eyes, both while it is in transit over a network and while it resides on systems.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.013
frontText: What is DLP and what can it do?
backText: DLP is data loss prevention. DLP systems help organizations enforce information handling policies and procedures to prevent data loss and theft.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.014
frontText: Name two different environments that DLP systems work in.
backText: Agent‐based DLP and agentless DLP

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.015
frontText: Name two mechanisms of action of DLP systems.
backText: Pattern matching and watermarking

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.016
frontText: What is data minimization and how can we do it?
backText: Data minimization techniques seek to reduce risk by reducing the amount of sensitive information that we maintain on a regular basis. The best way to achieve data minimization is to simply destroy data when it is no longer necessary to meet our original business purpose.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.017
frontText: What should we do if we can’t completely remove data from a dataset?
backText: We can transform it into a format where the original sensitive information is deidentified. The deidentification process removes the ability to link data back to an individual, reducing its sensitivity. An alternative to deidentifying data is transforming it into a format where the original information can’t be retrieved. This is a process called data obfuscation.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.018
frontText: Name some tools we can use in the process of data obfuscation.
backText: Hashing, tokenization, and masking

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.019
frontText: What are some examples of physical controls?
backText: Fences, perimeter lighting, locks, fire suppression systems, and burglar alarms

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.020
frontText: What are access restrictions?
backText: Access restrictions are security measures that limit the ability of individuals or systems to access sensitive information or resources.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.021
frontText: What are two types of access restrictions?
backText: Geographic restrictions and permission restrictions

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.022
frontText: What does segmentation accomplish?
backText: Segmentation places sensitive systems on separate networks where they may communicate with each other but have strict restrictions on their ability to communicate with systems on other networks.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.023
frontText: What does isolation do?
backText: Isolation goes a step further and completely cuts a system off from access to or from outside networks.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.024
frontText: What characteristics differentiate the types of cybersecurity threat actors?
backText: Internal vs. external, level of sophistication/capability, resources/funding, intent/motivation

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.025
frontText: What defines an unskilled attacker?
backText: The term unskilled attacker is a term used for people who use hacking techniques and premade tools but have limited skills.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.026
frontText: What is a hacktivist?
backText: A hacktivist uses hacking techniques to accomplish some activist goal.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.027
frontText: What is organized crime?
backText: Organized crime appears in any case where there is money to be made.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.028
frontText: What is a nation‐state actor?
backText: Nation‐state actors are sponsored by or supported by nations and are typically sophisticated and highly resourced.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.029
frontText: What is a zero‐day attack?
backText: Attacks that exploit vulnerabilities that are not yet disclosed.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.030
frontText: What term describes the means that an attacker uses to gain access to a system?
backText: Threat vectors are the means that threat actors use to obtain access to a system.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.031
frontText: What is threat intelligence?
backText: Threat intelligence is the set of activities and resources available to cybersecurity professionals seeking to learn about changes in the threat environment.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.032
frontText: What is open source threat intelligence?
backText: Open source threat intelligence is threat intelligence that is acquired from publicly available sources.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.033
frontText: What are three common questions that come into play when we assess a threat intelligence source or a specific threat intelligence notification?
backText: Is it timely? Is the information accurate? Is the information relevant?

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.034
frontText: Name some sources you can use when you build your threat research toolkit.
backText: Vendor security information websites, vulnerability and threat feeds from vendors, government agencies, and private organizations, academic journals and technical publications, professional conferences and local industry group meetings, and social media accounts of prominent security professionals

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.035
frontText: What type of attacker acts with authorization?
backText: An authorized attacker is one who acts with authorization and seeks to discover security vulnerabilities with the intent of correcting them.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.036
frontText: What type of attacker has a malicious intent?
backText: An unauthorized attacker

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.037
frontText: What type of attacker acts without proper authorization, but they do so with the intent of informing their targets of any security vulnerabilities?
backText: A semi‐authorized attacker

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.038
frontText: What is an insider threat?
backText: When an employee, contractor, vendor, or other individual with authorized access to information and systems uses that access to wage an attack against the organization

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.039
frontText: What is shadow IT?
backText: IT implementations, systems, and services created through unofficial means, often by well‐meaning employees or by employees outside of central IT.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.040
frontText: What actor is most commonly associated with corporate espionage?
backText: Competitors may engage in corporate espionage designed to steal sensitive information from your organization and use it to their own business advantage.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.041
frontText: Name 10 attacker motivations.
backText: Data exfiltration, espionage, service disruption, blackmail, financial gain, philosophical/political beliefs, ethical, revenge, disruption/chaos, and war.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.042
frontText: What is an attack surface?
backText: A system, application, or service that contains a vulnerability that attackers might exploit.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.043
frontText: Name eight threat vectors.
backText: Message‐based threat vectors, wired networks, wireless networks, systems, files and images, removable devices, cloud, and supply chain

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.044
frontText: What do you call a network run over standard Internet connections but using multiple layers of encryption to provide anonymous communication?
backText: Dark web

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.045
frontText: What do you call a geographic view of threat intelligence?
backText: A threat map.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.046
frontText: What is malware?
backText: The term malware describes a wide range of software that is intentionally designed to cause harm to systems and devices, networks, or users.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.047
frontText: What is ransomware?
backText: Ransomware is malware that takes over a computer then demands a ransom or payment.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.048
frontText: What control should organizations put in place to ensure that successful ransomware infections do not incapacitate the company?
backText: One of the most important defenses against ransomware is an effective backup system that stores files in a separate location that will not be impacted if the system or device it backs up is infected and encrypted by ransomware.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.049
frontText: What’s the difference between Trojans and worms?
backText: Trojans require user interaction, whereas worms are self‐installed and spread themselves.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.050
frontText: What are rootkits?
backText: Malware specifically designed to allow attackers to access a system through a backdoor.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.051
frontText: What is the best way to detect a rootkit?
backText: The best way to detect a rootkit is to test the suspected system from a trusted system or device. In cases where that isn’t possible, rootkit detection tools look for behaviors and signatures that are typical of rootkits.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.052
frontText: What are backdoors?
backText: Backdoors are methods or tools that provide access that bypasses normal authentication and authorization procedures, allowing attackers access to systems, devices, or applications.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.053
frontText: What are bots and what are botnets?
backText: Bots are remotely controlled systems or devices that have a malware infection. Groups of bots are known as botnets, and botnets are used by attackers who control them to perform various actions ranging from additional compromises and infection to denial‐of‐service (DoS) attacks or acting as spam relays.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.054
frontText: What are keyloggers?
backText: Programs that capture keystrokes from keyboards, although keylogger applications may also capture other input like mouse movement, touchscreen inputs, or credit card swipes from attached devices.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.055
frontText: What key element separates logic bombs from other malware?
backText: Logic bombs are functions or code that are placed inside other programs that will activate when set conditions are met instead of independent malicious programs.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.056
frontText: Name at least three types of viruses.
backText: Memory‐resident viruses, non‐memory resident viruses, boot sector viruses, macro viruses, and email viruses

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.057
frontText: Name at least five social engineering techniques.
backText: Phishing, vishing, smishing, misinformation, disinformation, business email compromise, pretexting, watering hole attack, impersonation, brand impersonation, and typosquatting.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.058
frontText: What is phishing?
backText: Phishing is a broad term used to describe the fraudulent acquisition of information, often focused on credentials like usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive personal information like credit card numbers and related data.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.059
frontText: Name three password‐related attacks.
backText: Brute‐force attacks, password spraying attacks, and dictionary attacks

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.060
frontText: What does the social engineering principle of authority rely on?
backText: Authority relies on the fact that most people will obey someone who appears to be in charge or knowledgeable, regardless of whether or not they actually are.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.061
frontText: What does the social engineering principle of intimidation rely on?
backText: Intimidation relies on scaring or bullying an individual into taking a desired action.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.062
frontText: What is the difference between misinformation and disinformation?
backText: Misinformation is incorrect information, often resulting from getting facts wrong. Disinformation is incorrect, inaccurate, or outright false information that is intentionally provided to serve an individual or organization’s goals.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.063
frontText: What is business email compromise?
backText: Business email compromise (BEC) relies on using apparently legitimate email addresses to conduct scams and other attacks.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.064
frontText: What do you call it when someone uses a made‐up scenario to justify why they are approaching an individual?
backText: Pretexting

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.065
frontText: What term describes an attack where an attacker uses websites that targets frequent to attack them?
backText: A watering hole attack

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.066
frontText: What is brand impersonation?
backText: An attack used in attempts to get users to log into their existing accounts, particularly for stores and banks.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.067
frontText: What is typosquatting?
backText: When attackers use misspelled and slightly off but similar to the legitimate site URLs and rely on the fact that people will mistype URLs and end up on their sites to drive up sales.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.068
frontText: Name five factors that influence how often an organization decides to conduct vulnerability scans against its systems.
backText: Risk appetite, regulatory requirements, technical constraints, business constraints, licensing limitations

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.069
frontText: Give some examples of controls that might affect scan results.
backText: Firewall settings, network segmentation, intrusion detection systems (IDSs), intrusion prevention systems (IPSs)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.070
frontText: Name the three techniques used by application testing and explain their differences.
backText: Static testing (analyzes code without executing it), dynamic testing (executes code as part of the test, running all the interfaces that the code exposes to the user with a variety of inputs, searching for vulnerabilities), and interactive testing (combines static and dynamic testing, analyzing the source code while testers interact with the application through exposed interfaces).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.071
frontText: What information does the output section provide on the report?
backText: The output section of the report shows the detailed information returned by the remote system when probed for the vulnerability, including the name of the vulnerability, overall severity, detailed description, solution, references, port/hosts, vulnerability information, and risk information.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.072
frontText: What information does the port/hosts section provide on the report?
backText: The port/hosts section provides details on the server(s) that contain the vulnerability as well as the specific services on that server that have the vulnerability.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.073
frontText: List all eight CVSS metrics and describe what kinds of measurements they evaluate.
backText: The eight Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) metrics are attack vector metric, attack complexity metric, privileges required metric, user interaction metric, confidentiality metric, integrity metric, availability metric, and scope metric. The first four measures evaluate the exploitability of the vulnerability, whereas the next three evaluate the impact of the vulnerability. The eighth metric discusses the scope of the vulnerability.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.074
frontText: What does the following CVSS vector mean? CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N
backText: Attack VectorNetwork (score0.85); Attack ComplexityLow (score0.77); Privileges RequiredNone (score0.85); User InteractionNone (score0.85); ScopeUnchanged; ConfidentialityHigh (score0.56); IntegrityNone (score0.00); AvailabilityNone (score0.00).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.075
frontText: What is the function to calculate the impact sub‐score?
backText: ISS = 1 – [(1 – Confidentiality) × (1 – Integrity) × (1 – Availability)]

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.076
frontText: How do you calculate the impact score for a vulnerability under CVSS?
backText: Impact score = the value of the scope metric * ISS

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.077
frontText: How do you calculate the exploitability score for a vulnerability under CVSS?
backText: Exploitability = 8.22 × AttackVector × AttackComplexity × PrivilegesRequired × UserInteraction

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.078
frontText: How do you calculate the CVSS base score for a vulnerability?
backText:
• If the impact is 0, the base score is 0.
  • If the scope metric is Unchanged, calculate the base score by adding together the impact and exploitability scores.
  • If the scope metric is Changed, calculate the base score by adding together the impact and exploitability scores and multiplying the result by 1.08.
  • The highest possible base score is 10. If the calculated value is greater than 10, set the base score to 10.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.079
frontText: Explain true positive, false positive, true negative, and false negative
backText: When a vulnerability scanner reports a vulnerability, this is known as a positive report. This report may either be accurate (a true positive report) or inaccurate (a false positive report). Similarly, when a scanner reports that a vulnerability is not present, this is a negative report. The negative report may either be accurate (a true negative report) or inaccurate (a false negative report).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.080
frontText: Give three valuable information sources for reconciling scan results.
backText: Log reviews from servers, applications, network devices, and other sources that might contain information about possible attempts to exploit detected vulnerabilities; security information and event management (SIEM) systems that correlate log entries from multiple sources and provide actionable intelligence; and configuration management systems that provide information on the operating system and applications installed on a system.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.081
frontText: Give some examples of weak configurations.
backText: The use of default settings that pose a security risk; the presence of default credentials or unsecured accounts, including both normal user accounts and unsecured root accounts with administrative privileges; open ports and services that are not necessary to support normal system operations; and open permissions that allow users access that violates the principle of least privilege.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.082
frontText: Name two choices you need to make when you implement encryption
backText: The algorithm to use to perform encryption and decryption; the encryption key to use with that algorithm

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.083
frontText: What are four major categories of penetration testing?
backText: Physical penetration testing, offensive penetration testing, defensive penetration testing, and integrated penetration testing.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.084
frontText: What are the benefits of penetration testing?
backText: Penetration testing provides us with knowledge that we can’t obtain elsewhere; in the event that attackers are successful, penetration testing provides us with an important blueprint for remediation; and penetration tests can provide us with essential, focused information on specific attack targets.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.085
frontText: What are three typical classifications that are used to describe penetration test types?
backText: Known environment, unknown environment, and partially known environment

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.086
frontText: List at least three key elements of the rules of engagement for a penetration test.
backText: The timeline for the engagement and when testing can be conducted; valid targets; data handling requirements; what behaviors to expect from the target; what resources are committed to the test; legal concerns should also be addressed, including a review of the laws that cover the target organization, any remote locations, and any service providers who will be in‐scope, and when and how communications will occur.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.087
frontText: Identify the four key phases of a penetration test.
backText: Initial access, privilege escalation, pivoting (lateral movement), and persistence

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.088
frontText: What are the three major components of a security assessment?
backText: Security tests, security assessments, and security audits

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.089
frontText: Name the phases of the software development life cycle (SDLC).
backText: Planning, requirements definition, design, coding, testing, training and transition, ongoing operations and maintenance, and end‐of‐life decommissioning

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.090
frontText: Name four code deployment environments.
backText: Development environment, test environment, staging environment, and production environment

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.091
frontText: What is the function of input validation?
backText: Input validation helps prevent a wide range of problems, from cross‐site scripting (XSS) to SQL injection (SQLi) attacks.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.092
frontText: What is parameter pollution?
backText: Parameter pollution is one technique that attackers have successfully used to defeat input validation controls.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.093
frontText: What is the function of a web application firewall?
backText: A web application firewall (WAF) plays an important role in protecting web applications against attacks. It sits in front of a web server and receives all network traffic headed to that server. It then scrutinizes the input headed to the application, performing input validation before passing the input to the web server.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.094
frontText: Describe the continuous integration (CI) and continuous deployment (CD) pipeline.
backText: Developer commits change, build process is triggered, build report is delivered, tests run against build, test report is delivered, and if successful, code is deployed.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.095
frontText: What are APIs?
backText: Application programming interfaces (APIs) are interfaces between clients and servers or applications and operating systems that define how the client should ask for information from the server and how the server will respond.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.096
frontText: Explain parameterized queries.
backText: Parameterized queries offer another technique to protect applications against injection attacks.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.097
frontText: What is sandboxing?
backText: The practice of running an application in a controlled or isolated environment to prevent it from interacting negatively with other system resources or applications.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.098
frontText: What is static code analysis and what is dynamic code analysis?
backText: Static code analysis (sometimes called source code analysis) is conducted by reviewing the code for an application. Static analysis does not run the program, instead it focuses on understanding how the program is written and what the code is intended to do. Dynamic code analysis relies on execution of the code while providing it with input to test the software.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.099
frontText: What does blind SQL injection (SQLi) mean and what are two forms of blind SQL injection?
backText: Attackers use a technique called blind SQL injection to conduct an attack even when they don’t have the ability to view the results directly. Two forms of blind SQL injection are content‐based and timing‐based.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.100
frontText: Give three ways that an attacker might discover a user’s password.
backText: Conducting social engineering attacks that trick the user into revealing a password, either directly or through a false authentication mechanism; eavesdropping on unencrypted network traffic; and obtaining a dump of passwords from previously compromised sites and assuming that a significant number of users reuse their passwords from that site on other sites.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.101
frontText: Give some ways that an attacker might obtain a cookie.
backText: Eavesdropping on unencrypted network connections and stealing a copy of the cookie as it is transmitted between the user and the website; installing malware on the user’s browser that retrieves cookies and transmits them back to the attacker, and engaging in an on‐path attack, where the attacker fools the user into thinking that the attacker is actually the target website and presenting a fake authentication form. They may then authenticate to the website on the user’s behalf and obtain the cookie.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.102
frontText: What is insecure direct object reference?
backText: If the application does not perform authorization checks, the user may be permitted to view information that exceeds their authority. This situation is known as an insecure direct object reference.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.103
frontText: What are two variants that file inclusion attacks come in? How do they work?
backText: Local file inclusion and remote file inclusion attacks. Local file inclusion attacks seek to execute code stored in a file located elsewhere on the web server. Remote file inclusion attacks allow the attacker to go a step further and execute code that is stored on a remote server.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.104
frontText: When would cross‐site scripting attacks occur?
backText: Cross‐site scripting (XSS) attacks occur when web applications allow an attacker to perform HTML injection, inserting their own HTML code into a web page.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.105
frontText: What’s the difference between cross‐site scripting attacks and cross‐site request forgery attacks?
backText: They exploit a different trust relationship. XSS attacks exploit the trust that a user has in a website to execute code on the user’s computer. XSRF attacks exploit the trust that remote sites have in a user’s system to execute commands on the user’s behalf.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.106
frontText: How do developers provide a way to confirm the authenticity of their code to end users?
backText: Through code signing. Developers digitally sign their code with their own private key and then browsers can use the developer’s public key to verify that signature and ensure that the code is legitimate and was not modified by unauthorized individuals.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.107
frontText: List and explain two principles we need to apply in application resilience.
backText: Scalability says that applications should be designed so that computing resources they require may be incrementally added to support increasing demand; elasticity goes a step further than scalability and says that applications should be able to automatically provision resources to scale when necessary and then automatically deprovision those resources to reduce capacity (and cost) when it is no longer needed.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.108
frontText: What is resource exhaustion?
backText: Resource exhaustion is when systems consume all of the memory, storage, processing time, or other resources available to them, rendering the system disabled or crippled for other uses.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.109
frontText: What is a cipher?
backText: A method used to scramble or obfuscate characters to hide their value. Ciphering is the process of using a cipher to do that type of scrambling to a message.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.110
frontText: What is the substitution cipher?
backText: A substitution cipher is a type of coding or ciphering system that changes one character or symbol into another.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.111
frontText: What term is used to describe using cryptographic techniques to embed secret messages within another file, such as hiding a message within an image file?
backText: Steganography is the art of using cryptographic techniques to embed secret messages within another file.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.112
frontText: What are four fundamental goals of cryptography?
backText: Confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and nonrepudiation.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.113
frontText: What is the difference between symmetric and asymmetric cryptography?
backText: Symmetric cryptosystems use a shared secret key available to all users of the cryptosystem. Asymmetric cryptosystems use individual combinations of public and private keys for each user of the system.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.114
frontText: What are three types of data we must think about when developing a cryptographic system for the purpose of providing confidentiality?
backText: Data at rest, data in transit, data in use

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.115
frontText: What are two major categories of modern ciphers and what are their methods of operation?
backText: Block ciphers operate on “chunks,” or blocks, of a message and apply the encryption algorithm to an entire message block at the same time. Stream ciphers operate on one character or bit of a message (or data stream) at a time.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.116
frontText: List some weaknesses of symmetric key cryptography.
backText: Key exchange is a major problem; symmetric key cryptography does not implement nonrepudiation; the algorithm is not scalable; and keys must be regenerated often

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.117
frontText: List some major strengths of asymmetric key cryptography.
backText: The addition of new users requires the generation of only one public‐private key pair; users can be removed far more easily from asymmetric systems; key regeneration is required only when a user’s private key is compromised; asymmetric key encryption can provide integrity, authentication, and nonrepudiation; key distribution is a simple process; and no preexisting communication link needs to exist.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.118
frontText: What is frequency analysis?
backText: Frequency analysis involves looking at the blocks of an encrypted message to determine if any common patterns exist.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.119
frontText: What is homomorphic encryption?
backText: Homomorphic encryption technology allows encrypting data in a way that preserves the ability to perform computation on that data.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.120
frontText: What are three key lengths allowed by the AES cipher and what are their corresponding number of encryption rounds?
backText: 128‐bit keys require 10 rounds of encryption; 192‐bit keys require 12 rounds of encryption; and 256‐bit keys require 14 rounds of encryption.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.121
frontText: What are three main methods used to exchange secret keys securely?
backText: Offline distribution, public key encryption, and the Diffie–Hellman key exchange algorithm

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.122
frontText: What are five basic requirements for a cryptographic hash function?
backText: They accept an input of any length; they produce an output of a fixed length; the hash value is relatively easy to compute; the hash function is one‐way (meaning that it is extremely hard to determine the input when provided with the output); and the hash function is collision free (meaning that it is extremely hard to find two messages that produce the same hash value).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.123
frontText: What are two distinct goals of digital signature infrastructure?
backText: Digitally signed messages assure the recipient that the message truly came from the claimed sender. They enforce nonrepudiation. Digitally signed messages assure the recipient that the message was not altered while in transit between the sender and recipient. This protects against both malicious modification and unintentional modification.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.124
frontText: What are some of the attributes used in an X.509 certificate?
backText: Version of X.509; serial number; signature algorithm identifier; issuer name; validity period; subject’s Common Name (CN); certificates may optionally contain Subject Alternative Names (SAN) that allow you to specify additional items (IP addresses, domain names, and so on) to be protected by the single certificate; and subject’s public key

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.125
frontText: Why might a certificate authority need to revoke a digital certificate?
backText: The certificate was compromised (e.g., the certificate owner accidentally gave away the private key); the certificate was erroneously issued (e.g., the CA mistakenly issued a certificate without proper verification); the details of the certificate changed (e.g., the subject’s name changed); and the security association changed (e.g., the subject is no longer employed by the organization sponsoring the certificate).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.126
frontText: What are three techniques to verify the authenticity of certificates and identify revoked certificates?
backText: Certificate revocation lists (CRLs), Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP), and certificate stapling

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.127
frontText: List five common ways to assert or claim an identity.
backText: Usernames, certificates, tokens, SSH keys, and smart cards.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.128
frontText: Name at least three authentication technologies.
backText: Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP), Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP), Password Authentication Protocol (PAP), 802.1X, Remote Authentication Dial‐In User Service (RADIUS), Terminal Access Controller Access Control System Plus (TACACS+), and Kerberos

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.129
frontText: What is SAML?
backText: Security Assertions Markup Language (SAML) is an XML‐based open standard for exchanging authentication and authorization information.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.130
frontText: What does an SSO system allow?
backText: Single sign‐on (SSO) systems allow a user to log in with a single identity, and then use multiple systems or services without reauthenticating.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.131
frontText: List four types of factors in multifactor authentication and explain them.
backText: Something you know, including passwords, PINs, or the answer to a security question; something you have, like a smartcard or token; something you are, which relies on a physical characteristic of the person who is authenticating themselves; and somewhere you are, sometimes called a location factor, is based on your current location. Location can be detected with GPS technology or viewing IP address information.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.132
frontText: What are two primary models for generation of one‐time passwords?
backText: TOTP, or time‐based one‐time passwords and HMAC‐based one‐time password (HOTP)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.133
frontText: List three common biometric technologies.
backText: Fingerprints, retina scanning, iris recognition; facial recognition; voice recognition; vein recognition, and gait analysis

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.134
frontText: What are password vaults?
backText: Software solutions that store, manage, and secure passwords and other information, allowing users to use strong passwords without memorizing dozens, or hundreds, of individual complex passwords.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.135
frontText: List common account types used for Windows systems.
backText: User accounts; privileged or administrative accounts; shared and generic accounts or credentials; guest accounts; and service accounts associated with applications and services

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.136
frontText: List and explain all three primary rules of role‐based access control (RBAC).
backText: Role assignment, which states that subjects can use only permissions that match a role they have been assigned; role authorization, which states that the subject’s active role must be authorized for the subject—this prevents subjects from taking on roles they shouldn’t be able to; and permission authorization, which states that subjects can only use permissions that their active role is allowed to use.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.137
frontText: Name five common access control schemes.
backText: Attribute‐based access control (ABAC), role‐based access control (RBAC), rule‐based access control (RBAC or RuBAC), mandatory access control (MAC), and discretionary access control (DAC)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.138
frontText: What are filesystem permissions?
backText: They determine which accounts, users, groups, or services can perform actions like reading, writing, and executing (running) files.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.139
frontText: List three common elements in designs for redundancy.
backText: Geographic dispersion of systems, separation of servers and other devices in datacenters, use of multiple network paths (multipath) solutions, redundant network devices, protection of power, systems and storage redundancy, and platform diversity

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.140
frontText: List at least three backup and replication methods.
backText: RAID, journaling, full and incremental backups, snapshots, images, copies of individual files, backup media, cloud backups, and off‐site or on‐site storage

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.141
frontText: What is RAID 5 and what are its advantages and disadvantages?
backText: RAID 5 is a solution in which data is striped across drives, with one drive used for parity (checksum) of the data. Parity is spread across drives as well as data. RAID 5’s advantages are that data reads are fast; drive failures can be rebuilt as long as only one drive fails. RAID 5’s disadvantages are that it can only tolerate a single drive failure at a time, data writes are slightly slower, and rebuilding arrays after a drive loss can be slow and impact performance.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.142
frontText: Give four important considerations that come into play with cloud and off‐site third‐party backup options.
backText: Bandwidth requirements for both the backups themselves and restoration time if the backup needs to be restored partially or fully; time to retrieve files and cost to retrieve files; reliability is also crucial; and new security models may also be required for backups.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.143
frontText: List and explain two categories of scalability and their advantages.
backText: Vertical scalability uses a more capable system or device and helps when all tasks or functions need to be handled on the same system or infrastructure. Horizontal scaling uses more smaller systems or devices. A horizontally scaled system can take advantage of the ability to transparently add and remove more resources, allowing it to adjust as needs grow or shrink and allows opportunities for transparent upgrades, patching, and even incident response.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.144
frontText: What are three major types of disaster recovery sites used for site resilience?
backText: Hot sites, warm sites, and cold sites

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.145
frontText: List all steps in site restoration.
backText: Restore network connectivity and a bastion or shell host; restore network security devices (firewalls, IPS); restore storage and database services; restore critical operational servers; restore logging and monitoring service; and restore other services as soon as possible.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.146
frontText: What is a bollard?
backText: Bollards are posts or other obstacles that prevent vehicles from moving through an area. Bollards may look like posts, pillars, or even planters, but their purpose remains the same: preventing vehicle access.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.147
frontText: What is an access control vestibule?
backText: An access control vestibule is a pair of doors that both require some form of authorized access to open. The first door opens after authorization, closes, and only after it is closed can the person who wants to enter provide their authorization to open the second door.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.148
frontText: What are the advantages of guards?
backText: Guards can make decisions that technical control systems cannot, and they provide additional capabilities by offering both detection and response capabilities. Guards can validate an individual’s identity, ensure that they enter only the areas they are supposed to, and ensure that they have signed a visitor log and that their signature matches a signature on file or on their ID card.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.149
frontText: What are the disadvantages of guards?
backText: Guards can be fallible, and social engineering attempts can persuade guards to violate policies or even to provide attackers with assistance. Guards are relatively expensive.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.150
frontText: What are two types of advanced security camera capabilities?
backText: Motion recognition and object detection

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.151
frontText: What are three areas for capacity planning?
backText: Three areas for capacity planning are people, technology, and infrastructure.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.152
frontText: What are four common methods of testing resilience and recovery controls?
backText: Tabletop exercises, simulation exercises, parallel processing, and failover exercises

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.153
frontText: What are infrared sensors?
backText: They rely on infrared light, or heat radiation. They look for changes in infrared radiation in a room or space and alert when that change occurs.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.154
frontText: What are pressure sensors?
backText: They detect a change in pressure. While not commonly deployed in most environments, they may be used when an organization needs to detect an object being moved or when someone is moving through an area using a pressure plate or pad.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.155
frontText: What are microwave sensors?
backText: Microwave sensors use a baseline for a room or space that is generated by detecting normal responses when the space is at a baseline. When those responses to the microwaves sent out by the sensor change, they will trigger. They can detect motion through materials that infrared sensors cannot.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.156
frontText: Describe how RFID cloning attacks work.
backText: RFID cloning attacks work by cloning an RFID tag or card.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.157
frontText: How do environmental attacks work?
backText: Environmental attacks include attacks like targeting an organization’s heating and cooling systems, maliciously activating a sprinkler system, and similar actions.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.158
frontText: What is cloud computing?
backText: A model for enabling ubiquitous, convenient, on‐demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources (e.g., networks, servers, storage, applications, and services) that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort or service provider interaction.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.159
frontText: What are the key benefits of the cloud?
backText: On‐demand self‐service computing, scalability, elasticity, measured service, agility and flexibility

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.160
frontText: List and explain the five key cloud roles.
backText: Cloud service providers offer cloud computing services; cloud consumers purchase cloud services from cloud service providers; cloud partners and brokers offer ancillary products that support or integrate with the offerings of a cloud service provider; cloud auditors are independent organizations that provide assessments of cloud services and operations; cloud carriers serve provide connectivity that allows the delivery of cloud services from providers to consumers.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.161
frontText: What are three major cloud service models?
backText: Infrastructure as a service (IaaS), software as a service (SaaS), and platform as a service (PaaS)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.162
frontText: List the four cloud deployment models.
backText: Public cloud, private cloud, community cloud, and hybrid cloud.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.163
frontText: What is the primary responsibility of the hypervisor?
backText: The primary responsibility of the hypervisor is enforcing isolation between virtual machines. This means that the hypervisor must present each virtual machine with the illusion of a completely separate physical environment dedicated for use by that virtual machine.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.164
frontText: What are two primary types of hypervisors and what are their differences?
backText: Type I hypervisors, also known as bare‐metal hypervisors, operate directly on top of the underlying hardware. This is the model most commonly used in datacenter virtualization because it is highly efficient. Type II hypervisors run as an application on top of an existing operating system. In this approach, the operating system supports the hypervisor and the hypervisor requests resources for each guest operating system from the host operating system.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.165
frontText: What are two categories of cloud storage offerings?
backText: Block storage allocates large volumes of storage for use by virtual server instance(s). Object storage provides customers with the ability to place files in buckets and treat each file as an independent entity that may be accessed over the web or through the provider’s API.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.166
frontText: What are three key security considerations when working with cloud storage?
backText: Set permissions properly; consider high availability and durability options; and use encryption to protect sensitive data.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.167
frontText: What principle states that data is subject to the legal restrictions of any jurisdiction where it is collected, stored, or processed?
backText: Data sovereignty is a principle that states that data is subject to the legal restrictions of any jurisdiction where it is collected, stored, or processed.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.168
frontText: What are two different approaches to cloud access security broker (CASB) solutions?
backText: Inline CASB solutions physically or logically reside in the connection path between the user and the service and can see requests before they are sent to the cloud service, allowing the CASB to block requests that violate policy. API‐based CASB solutions do not interact directly with the user but rather interact directly with the cloud provider through the provider’s API. This approach provides direct access to the cloud service without custom user device configuration.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.169
frontText: What term describes an organization that offers services such as security monitoring, vulnerability management, incident response, and firewall management?
backText: Managed security service provider (MSSP).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.170
frontText: What provides application‐level virtualization?
backText: A container.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.171
frontText: What allows engineers to interact with and modify cloud resources through their APIs?
backText: Software‐defined networking (SDN).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.172
frontText: What provides cybersecurity professionals with insight into the traffic on their virtual networks?
backText: Software‐defined visibility (SDV).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.173
frontText: What is the function of security groups?
backText: They define permissible network traffic.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.174
frontText: What is the function of segmentation?
backText: It allows network engineers to place systems of differing security levels and functions on different network subnets.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.175
frontText: What is the function of virtual private clouds?
backText: VPCs are used to group systems into subnets and designate those subnets as public or private, depending on whether access to them is permitted from the Internet.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.176
frontText: What is the function of a hardware security module (HSM)?
backText: HSMs manage encryption keys and perform cryptographic operations efficiently.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.177
frontText: What are two different techniques to ensure that the system is secure that modern UEFI firmware can leverage?
backText: Secure boot ensures that the system boots using only software that the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) trusts. Measured boot is intended to help prevent boot‐level malware. Measured boot processes measure each component, starting with the firmware and ending with the boot start drivers.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.178
frontText: List four common methods to detect malicious software and applications.
backText: Signature‐based detection; heuristic or behavior‐based detection; artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) systems; and sandboxing

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.179
frontText: What are allow and deny lists?
backText: An allow list allows you to build a list of software, applications, and other system components that are allowed to exist and run on a system. If they are not on the allow list, they will be removed, disabled, or will not be able to be installed. Deny lists are lists of software or applications that cannot be installed or run, rather than a list of what is allowed.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.180
frontText: Give some types of configuration settings recommended by CIS benchmark for Windows.
backText: Setting the password history to remember 24 or more passwords and setting maximum passwords age to “60 or fewer days, but not 0,” preventing users from simply changing their passwords 24 times to get back to the same password while requiring password changes every 2 months. Setting the minimum password length to 14 or more characters. Requiring password complexity. Disabling the storage of passwords using reversible encryption

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.181
frontText: How does FDE work?
backText: Full disk encryption (FDE) encrypts the disk and requires that the bootloader or a hardware device provide a decryption key and software or hardware to decrypt the drive for use.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.182
frontText: What kinds of potential downfalls does disk encryption bring?
backText: If the encryption key is lost, the data on the drive will likely be unrecoverable since the same strong encryption that protects it will make it unlikely that you will be able to brute‐force the key and acquire the data. Technical support can be more challenging, and data corruption or other issues can have a larger impact, resulting in unrecoverable data.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.183
frontText: What steps can be used to assess embedded systems?
backText:
• Identify the manufacturer Determine how the embedded system interfaces with the world: Identify services and their security
  • Check for patches and patch availability
  • Document response and support processes

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.184
frontText: What kinds of issues should security analysts be aware of when dealing with IoT devices?
backText: Poor security practices including weak default settings, lack of network security (firewalls), exposed or vulnerable services, lack of encryption for data transfer, weak authentication, use of embedded credentials and insecure data storage; Short support lifespans; Vendor data handling practice issues.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.185
frontText: What security constraints do you need to take into account when you consider security for embedded systems?
backText: The overall computational power and capacity of embedded systems is usually much lower than a traditional PC or mobile device; embedded systems may not connect to a network; without network connectivity, CPU and memory capacity, and other elements, authentication is also likely to be impossible; and embedded systems may be very low cost, but many are effectively very high cost because they are a component in a larger industrial or specialized device.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.186
frontText: What are three major functions provided by TPM chips?
backText: Trusted Platform Module (TPM) chips are frequently used to provide built‐in encryption, and they provide three major functions: remote attestation, allowing hardware and software configurations to be verified; binding, which encrypts data; and sealing, which encrypts data and sets requirements for the state of the TPM chip before decryption.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.187
frontText: What are HSMs?
backText: Hardware security modules (HSMs) are typically external devices or plug‐in cards used to create, store, and manage digital keys for cryptographic functions and authentication, as well as to offload cryptographic processing.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.188
frontText: What are cryptographic key management systems used for?
backText: Cryptographic key management systems are used to store keys and certificates as well as to manage them centrally.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.189
frontText: Describe EDR.
backText: Endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools combine monitoring capabilities on endpoint devices and systems using a client or software agent with network monitoring and log analysis capabilities to collect, correlate, and analyze events. Key features of EDR systems are the ability to search and explore the collected data and to use it for investigations as well as the ability to detect suspicious data.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.190
frontText: Describe key elements of DLP.
backText: Key elements of data loss prevention (DLP) systems are the ability to classify data so that organizations know which data should be protected; data labeling or tagging functions, to support classification and management practices; policy management and enforcement functions used to manage data to the standards set by the organization; and monitoring and reporting capabilities, to quickly notify administrators or security practitioners about issues or potential problems.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.191
frontText: Name three endpoint protection solutions.
backText: Host‐based firewall, host intrusion prevention system (HIPS), and host intrusion detection system (HIDS)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.192
frontText: What is one of the fastest ways to decrease the attack surface of a system?
backText: Reducing the number of open ports and services that it provides by disabling ports and protocols.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.193
frontText: What are a few network hardening techniques?
backText: The use of VLANs to segment different trust levels, user groups, or systems; placing IoT devices on a separate, protected VLAN; using a VLAN for guest networks or to isolate VoIP phones from workstations; changing default passwords; and removing unnecessary software.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.194
frontText: What are three phases of a baseline’s life cycle?
backText: Establishing a baseline, deploying the security baseline, and maintaining the baseline

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.195
frontText: How does network segmentation work?
backText: It divides a network up into logical or physical groupings that are frequently based on trust boundaries, functional requirements, or other reasons that help an organization apply controls or assist with functionality.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.196
frontText: What are two common NAC usage models?
backText: Network access control (NAC) can use a software agent that is installed on the computer to perform security checks, or it may be agentless and run from a browser or via another means without installing software locally.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.197
frontText: What is port security?
backText: A capability that allows you to limit the number of MAC addresses that can be used on a single port.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.198
frontText: List four types of protocol‐level protections.
backText: Loop prevention, broadcast storm prevention, bridge protocol data unit (BPDU) guard, and Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) snooping

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.199
frontText: What are port mirrors and a SPAN?
backText: A port mirror sends a copy of all the traffic sent to one switch port to another switch port for monitoring. A SPAN can do the same thing but can also combine traffic from multiple ports to a single port for analysis.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.200
frontText: What is a VPN?
backText: A virtual private network (VPN) is a way to create a virtual network link across a public network that allows the endpoints to act as though they are on the same network.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.201
frontText: What are two decision points for VPN implementation?
backText: Whether the VPN will be used for remote access, or if it will be a site‐to‐site VPN; and whether they will be a split‐tunnel VPN or a full‐tunnel VPN

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.202
frontText: Explain active/active vs. active/passive load balancers.
backText: Active/active load balancer designs distribute the load among multiple systems that are online and in use at the same time. Active/passive load balancer designs bring backup or secondary systems online when an active system is removed or fails to respond properly to a health check.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.203
frontText: What are two types of proxy servers?
backText: Forward proxies are placed between clients and servers, and they accept requests from clients and send them forward to servers. Reverse proxies are placed between servers and clients, and they are used to help with load balancing and caching of content.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.204
frontText: What are the three common detection methods to identify unwanted and potentially malicious traffic?
backText: Signature‐based detections rely on a known hash or signature matching to detect a threat. Heuristic or behavior‐based detections look for specific patterns or sets of actions that match threat behaviors. Anomaly‐based detections establish a baseline for an organization or network and then flags when out‐of‐the‐ordinary behavior occurs.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.205
frontText: What are the differences between stateless firewalls and stateful firewalls?
backText: Stateless firewalls (sometimes called packet filters) filter every packet based on data like the source and destination IP and port, the protocol, and other information that can be gleaned from the packet’s headers, whereas stateful firewalls (sometimes called dynamic packet filters) pay attention to the state of traffic between systems.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.206
frontText: What are web application firewalls?
backText: Security devices that are designed to be able to intercept, analyze, and apply rules to web traffic, including tools like database queries, APIs, and other web application tools.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.207
frontText: What are four types of information‐gathering tools included in the Security+ exam outline?
backText: Honeypots are configured to appear to be vulnerable and are heavily instrumented to record what an attacker does. Honeynets are networks set up to collect information about network attacks. A honeyfile is an intentionally attractive file that contains unique, detectable data that is left in an area for attackers to take. Honeytokens are data intended to be attractive to attackers used to allow security professionals to track data.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.208
frontText: What is an on‐path attack?
backText: Occurs when an attacker causes traffic that should be sent to its intended recipient to be relayed through a system or device the attacker controls.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.209
frontText: Which term describes the points at which an unauthorized user could gain access?
backText: Attack surface

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.210
frontText: What are security zones?
backText: Network segments, physical or virtual network segments, or other components of an infrastructure that are able to be separate from less secure zones through logical or physical means.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.211
frontText: What is SDN?
backText: Software‐defined networking (SDN) uses software‐based network configuration to control networks. SDN designs rely on controllers that manage network devices and configurations, centrally managing the software‐defined network.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.212
frontText: Describe SASE.
backText: Secure access service edge (SASE) combines VPNs, SD‐WAN, and cloud‐based security tools like firewalls, CASBs, and zero‐trust networks to provide secure access for devices regardless of their location.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.213
frontText: Describe how zero trust works.
backText: Zero trust presumes that there is no trust boundary and no network edge. Each action is validated when requested as part of a continuous authentication process and access is only allowed after policies are checked, including elements like identity, permissions, system configuration and security status, threat intelligence data review, and security posture.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.214
frontText: What do administrators use as a way to securely operate in security zones with different security levels?
backText: Jump servers

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.215
frontText: Describe the functions of DKIM, SPF, and DMARC in protecting email.
backText: DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) allows organizations to add content to messages to identify them as being from their domain. Sender Policy Framework (SPF) allows organizations to publish a list of their authorized email servers. SPF records specify which systems are allowed to send email from that domain. Domain‐based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) is a protocol that uses SPF and DKIM to determine if an email message is authentic.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.216
frontText: List at least five connectivity methods.
backText: Cellular, Wi‐Fi, Bluetooth, NFC, RFID, Infrared, GPS, USB

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.217
frontText: What is NFC and how is it most frequently used?
backText: NFC, or near‐field communication, is used for very short range communication between devices. You’ve likely seen NFC used for payment terminals using Apple Pay or Google Wallet using cell phones. NFC is limited to short range, meaning that it is not used to build networks of devices, and instead it is primarily used for low bandwidth, device to device purposes.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.218
frontText: What is RFID?
backText: RFID (Radio Frequency Identification) is a relatively short range (from less than a foot of some passive tags to about 100 meters for active tags) wireless technology that uses a tag and a receiver to exchange information.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.219
frontText: What is an evil twin?
backText: A malicious fake access point that is set up to appear to be a legitimate, trusted network.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.220
frontText: What are two types of Bluetooth attacks and what are their differences?
backText: Bluejacking sends unsolicited messages to Bluetooth‐enabled devices. Bluesnarfing is unauthorized access to a Bluetooth device, typically aimed at gathering information like contact lists or other details the device contains.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.221
frontText: What are two major usage modes provided by WPA3?
backText: WPA‐Personal uses Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE) mode to provide authentication while protecting against offline dictionary attacks. This allows clients to authenticate without an authentication server infrastructure. The other is WPA‐Enterprise, which relies on a RADIUS authentication server as part of an 802.1X implementation for authentication. This means users can have unique credentials and can be individually identified.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.222
frontText: List and explain three major types of authentication in modern Wi‐Fi networks.
backText: Open networks do not require authentication or use encryption and often use a captive portal to information from users. Preshared keys (PSK) require that a passphrase or key is shared with anybody who wants to use the network and provides encryption. Enterprise authentication relies on a RADIUS server and utilizes an EAP protocol for authentication.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.223
frontText: Name four common mobile device deployment and management models.
backText: BYOD (bring your own device), CYOD (choose your own device) COPE (Corporate owned, personally enabled), and corporate owned

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.224
frontText: Give three examples of features that an organization may want or need to ensure that mobile devices and the data they contain are secure.
backText: Application management Content management. Remote wipe Geolocation and geofencing Screen locks, passwords, and PINs are all part of normal device security models to prevent unauthorized access. Biometrics Context‐aware authentication Containerization is an increasingly common solution to handling separation of work and personal use contexts on devices. Storage segmentation can be used to keep personal and business data separate as well. Full‐device encryption (FDE)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.225
frontText: How do organizations determine where to place access points to handle poor coverage areas?
backText: They conduct site surveys and create heat maps showing where coverage is relative to existing access points.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.226
frontText: Organizations that want to determine what software and configurations are used on mobile devices should deploy what type of solution?
backText: Mobile device management (MDM)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.227
frontText: What are six steps in the incident response process?
backText: Preparation, identification, containment, eradication, recovery, and lessons learned

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.228
frontText: Who are the typical team members in an incident response team?
backText: Members of management or organizational leadership, technical experts, communications and public relations staff, legal and human relations staff, law enforcement

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.229
frontText: What are the three major types of exercises that incident response teams use to prepare?
backText: Tabletop, walkthroughs, simulations

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.230
frontText: List four incident response plan types.
backText: Communication plans, stakeholder management plans, business continuity plans, and disaster recovery plans

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.231
frontText: Name seven elements in the security information and event management system.
backText: SIEM dashboard, sensors, sensitivity and threshold, trends, alerts and alarms, correlation and analysis, rules.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.232
frontText: List 5 common logs used by incident responders.
backText: System logs, application logs, security logs, vulnerability scan output, network and security device logs, web logs, DNS logs, authentication logs, dump files, and VoIP and SIP logs.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.233
frontText: What are playbooks?
backText: Step‐by‐step guides intended to help incident response teams take the right steps in a given scenario.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.234
frontText: What are runbooks?
backText: The operational procedures guides that organizations use to perform actions.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.235
frontText: List three techniques that support removing systems, devices, or even entire network segments or zones.
backText: Isolation, containment, segmentation

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.236
frontText: What type of testing involves discussing what a staff member would do in a given scenario?
backText: Tabletop exercises leverage discussions and conversations to help organizations prepare for actual events.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.237
frontText: After an event or incident, what process is used to determine why it occurred?
backText: Root cause analysis is used to determine why an event or issue occurred

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.238
frontText: What are the 9 stages in the EDRM model?
backText:
Information governance
Identification of electronically stored information
Preservation of the information
Collection of the information
Processing of the data
Review of the data
Analysis of the information
Production of the data
Presentation for testimony in court and for further analysis

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.239
frontText: List the order of volatility.
backText:
From most volatile to least volatile:
CPU cache and register; ephemeral data such as the process table, kernel statistics, the system’s ARP cache, and similar information; the content of RAM; swap and pagefile information; files and data on a disk; the operating system (Windows Registry); data on devices such as smartphones, tables, IoT devices, and embedded or specialized systems; firmware; snapshots from VMs; network traffic and logs; and artifacts like devices, printouts, media, and other items.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.240
frontText: What is a right‐to‐audit clause?
backText: Part of the contract between the cloud service and an organization. A right‐to‐audit clause provides either a direct ability to audit the cloud provider or an agreement to use a third‐party audit agency.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.241
frontText: What is the Linux dd command? Give an example to copy a drive mounted as /dev/sda to a file called example.img.
backText: The Linux dd command is a command‐line utility that allows you to create disk images for forensic or other purposes.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.242
frontText: What are common elements in a typical forensic report?
backText: A summary of the forensic investigation and findings; an outline of the forensic process, including tools used and any assumptions that were made about the tools or process; a series of sections detailing the findings for each device or drive—accuracy is critical when findings are shared, and conclusions must be backed up with evidence and appropriate detail; and recommendations or conclusions in more detail than the summary included.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.243
frontText: What ensures that acquired images are intact?
backText: Hashing and validating

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.244
frontText: Name four use cases for forensics.
backText: Forensics may be used for investigations, incident response, intelligence, and counterintelligence.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.245
frontText: What is used to ensure that organization that may be engaged in litigation retain relevant data?
backText: A legal hold.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.246
frontText: What documentation is created to demonstrate that forensic data and artifacts were handled properly and that they were not modified or changed during the forensic process?
backText: Chain‐of‐custody documentation.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.247
frontText: What is the process of obtaining and protecting forensic data called?
backText: Preservation

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.248
frontText: What is the process of conducting a digital investigation intended to find artifacts related to criminal activity or for litigation called?
backText: E‐discovery

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.249
frontText: What are four types of documents in the information security policy framework?
backText: Policies, standards, procedures, and guidelines

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.250
frontText: What term is used for a document that provides a high‐level statement of management intent?
backText: A policy

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.251
frontText: What do you call a document that provides mandatory requirements describing how an organization will carry out its information security policies?
backText: A standard

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.252
frontText: What do you call a document that provides best practices and recommendations related to a given concept, technology, or task?
backText: A guideline

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.253
frontText: What is the primary goal of change management?
backText: To ensure that changes do not cause outages.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.254
frontText: What do many organizations use to coordinate changes to information systems?
backText: Maintenance windows.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.255
frontText: List the criteria that must be met for a compensating control to be satisfactory under PCI DSS.
backText: Controls must meet the intent and rigor of the original requirement and must provide a similar level of defense, and must sufficiently offset the risk that the original PCI DSS requirement addressed. Existing PCI DSS requirements cannot be considered as compensating controls if they’re already required for other assessed items, existing requirements may be considered as compensating controls if they are required for another area but are not required for the item under review.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.256
frontText: What principle says that individuals should only be granted the minimum set of permissions necessary to carry out their job functions?
backText: The principle of least privilege says that individuals should only be granted the minimum set of permissions necessary to carry out their job functions.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.257
frontText: Give three examples of personnel management practices.
backText: Least privilege, separation of duties, job rotation and mandatory vacations, clean desk space, onboarding and offboarding, nondisclosure agreements (NDAs), social media, and user training.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.258
frontText: List four standard agreements used in third‐party risk management.
backText: Master service agreements (MSA), service level agreements (SLAs), memorandum of understanding (MOU), memorandum of agreement (MOA), and business partners agreements (BPAs).

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.259
frontText: What is the purpose of version control?
backText: It ensures that developers and users have access to the latest versions of software and that changes are carefully managed throughout the release process.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.260
frontText: What are three components in the NIST framework?
backText: The Framework Core, the Framework Implementation, and the Framework Profile

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.261
frontText: What is the difference between an audit and an assessment?
backText: Audits are formal reviews of an organization’s security program or specific compliance issues conducted on behalf of a third party. Assessments are less formal reviews of security controls that are typically requested by the security organization itself in an effort to engage in process improvement.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.262
frontText: What is crucial for managing and mitigating third‐party risks?
backText: Effective vendor monitoring is crucial for managing and mitigating third‐party risks.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.263
frontText: What does establishing rules of engagement do?
backText: Establishing rules of engagement helps define the boundaries within which the vendor should operate. They normally include setting clear communication protocols, defining responsibilities, and establishing processes for issue resolution.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.264
frontText: Why should a company establish key performance indicators (KPIs)?
backText: KPIs quantitatively measure vendors’ performance in order to ensure that vendors are meeting the agreed‐upon standards.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.265
frontText: Name six major information security regulations facing organizations.
backText: HIPAA, PCI DSS, GLBA, SOX, GDPR, and FERPA

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.266
frontText: Define due care.
backText: It refers to the ongoing efforts to ensure that the implemented policies and controls are effective and continuously maintained.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.267
frontText: What are threats, vulnerabilities, and risks?
backText: Threats are any possible events that might have an adverse impact on the confidentiality, integrity, and/or availability of our information or information systems. Vulnerabilities are weaknesses in our systems or controls that could be exploited by a threat. Risks occur at the intersection of a vulnerability and a threat that might exploit that vulnerability. A threat without a corresponding vulnerability does not pose a risk, nor does a vulnerability without a corresponding threat.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.268
frontText: What is the formula to calculate the severity of a risk?
backText: Risk Severity = Likelihood * Impact

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.269
frontText: What are two types of risk analyses and what are their differences?
backText: Quantitative risk analyses use numeric data, resulting in assessments that allow the very straightforward prioritization of risks. Qualitative risk analysis substitutes subjective judgments and categories for strict numerical analysis, allowing the assessment of risks that are difficult to quantify.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.270
frontText: Describe the process of quantitative risk analysis.
backText: Determine the asset value (AV) of the asset affected by the risk. Determine the likelihood that the risk will occur. Determine the amount of damage that will occur to the asset if the risk materializes. Calculate the single loss expectancy. Calculate the annualized loss expectancy.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.271
frontText: What are two important roles served by risk assessment in the risk management process?
backText: The risk analysis provides guidance in prioritizing risks so that the risks with the highest probability and magnitude are addressed first. Quantitative risk analyses help determine whether the potential impact of a risk justifies the costs incurred by adopting a risk management approach.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.272
frontText: What is risk mitigation?
backText: The process of applying security controls to reduce the probability and/or magnitude of a risk.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.273
frontText: What is risk avoidance?
backText: A risk management strategy where you change your business practices to completely eliminate the potential that a risk will materialize.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.274
frontText: What term describes the original level of risk that exists before implementing any controls?
backText: The inherent risk facing an organization is the original level of risk that exists before implementing any controls. Inherent risk takes its name from the fact that it is the level of risk inherent in the organization’s business.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.275
frontText: What are four key metrics in the BIA process?
backText: Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF) is the expected amount of time between system failures. Mean Time to Repair (MTTR) is the average amount of time to restore a system to its normal operating state after a failure. Recovery Time Objective (RTO) is the amount of time that the organization can tolerate a system being down before it is repaired. Recovery Point Objective (RPO) is the amount of data that the organization can tolerate losing during an outage.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.276
frontText: What category of information includes any information that uniquely identifies an individual person, including customers, employees, and third parties?
backText: Personally identifiable information (PII) includes any information that uniquely identifies an individual person, including customers, employees, and third parties.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.277
frontText: What term refers to medical records maintained by health‐care providers and other organizations that are subject to HIPAA?
backText: Protected health information (PHI)

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.278
frontText: What are the four major information classification categories used by the U.S. government?
backText: Top secret, secret, confidential, and unclassified

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.279
frontText: What are three tools that can be used in the data obfuscation process?
backText: Hashing uses a hash function to transform a value in our dataset to a corresponding hash value. Tokenization replaces sensitive values with a unique identifier using a lookup table. Data masking partially redacts sensitive information by replacing some or all of sensitive fields with blank characters.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.280
frontText: What is a data subject?
backText: An individual whose personal data is being processed.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.281
frontText: What is a data controller?
backText: The entity who determines the reasons for processing personal information and directs the methods of processing that data.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.282
frontText: What is a data steward?
backText: An individual who carries out the intent of the data controller or stewardship responsibility but is responsible for the secure safekeeping of information.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.283
frontText: What is a data custodian?
backText: An individual or team who does not have controller or stewardship responsibility but is responsible for the secure safekeeping of information.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.284
frontText: What is a data processor?
backText: A service provider that processes personal information on behalf of a data controller.

title: fc211418.SecplSG9E.285
frontText: What is a data protection officer (DPO)?
backText: The European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) requires that every data controller designate a data protection officer (DPO) who bears overall responsibility for carrying out the organization’s data privacy efforts.
